documents.title: our live coverage today
text: that 's it for our regular news updates for today - and for the week .

our main stories today have been the inquest into the death of a man from poland , who drowned after getting caught in a rip tide at sea palling , and the mother from west norfolk who 's been refused permission to stay here after her visa expired .
norwich city travel to brighton tomorrow for the championship - and it 's touch and go for pinto .
on a lighter note , a hallowe'en cake baked by norfolk 's great british bake off contestant kate barmby has raised £ 440 for pudsey .

the cake was auctioned live on bbc radio norfolk , as part of its fundraising for bbc children in need - and the winning bid was donated by the staff at perfect placement website at the st andrews business park near norwich .

the staff regularly hold bake-off fundraisers for charities and were over the moon to receive the hallowe-en themed cake from kate at their office - but they 're not sure that they can cut into it because it looks so good .

finally - good luck to norwich city chairman ed balls , who 's dancing the cha cha to love potion no 9 in a hallowe'en edition of strictly come dancing tomorrow night - let 's hope it 's not a nightmare for him .
have a great weekend - we 'll be back at 08:00 on monday .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: visa couple in limbowaiting for images
text: alex chapman came to norfolk from her native new zealand and got married to a local farmer will chapman four years ago .
they live in oxborough , near king 's lynn , with their five-month-old daughter olivia , and wish to stay together as a family .
but the home office has refused her permission to remain here .
28-year-old alex 's visa expired last december - it was just after christmas when the family heard her application to remain here with her family was refused .
the home office was n't satisfied with information about her means - and was n't convinced it would pose serious hardship for the couple to live outside the uk , in new zealand .
alex works in the office of wr chapman and son , which is run by her husband where she draws a salary of about £ 11,000 .
the couple have already spent £ 5,000 on legal fees and costs and it will cost thousands more to be represented at an appeal hearing scheduled for next february , but now postponed .
in the meantime , her new zealand passport is held by the home office and the couple remain in limbo .
we 've contacted the home office for their statement , but are still waiting to hear from them
author: Kim Riley
BBC Look East

documents.title: norfolk 's hospitals are £ 34m in the red
text: hospitals in norfolk are millions of pounds in the red this year , despite having made huge savings .

the government has put in an extra £ 1.8bn to help the nhs in england to end deficits by 2017/18 , but sunday politics east has discovered that this year hospitals in our region are running deficits of £ 336 million in total .

in norfolk , the queen elizabeth hospital in king 's lynn is expecting to be running a £ 5.3m deficit by the end of this financial year , while the norfolk and norwich university hospital will have a £ 31m hole in its finances .
the james paget hospital at gorleston is one of the few balancing its books and expects a £ 2m surplus by 2017 .
in all that 's a £ 34 million shortfall across the county 's acute hospitals .
hospitals have been given special funds by the department of health but only on the condition that they hit agreed savings targets .
all but two of the acute hospitals in the east are in deficit .
author: Deborah McGurran
BBC Political editor, East of England

documents.title: the fight to tackle rural crime
text: people in rural communities , businesses and land owners are attending a summit where they 'll be hearing how norfolk 's police and crime commissioner ( pcc ) plans to tackle countryside crime .
earlier this year , there were nearly 30 thefts in the space of three weeks in the south of the county , and the national farmers union is paying out more and more in insurance .
pcc lorne green says he 'll `` throw more resources '' at the problem : `` we started with six officers , boosted this to 12 and will go to 20 by the new year . ''

asst ch constable nick dean says the police alone ca n't tackle crime : `` it 's a joint approach - we look to members of the community to come forward with information and intelligence that we link and piece together . ''
so how will mr green fund his fight against rural crime ?
we 'll do better with what we have and redirect resources to where the needs are greatest .
there are special challenges in the rural area and we 're going to throw more resources at it . ''

documents.title: unaccompanied child migrants to come to norfolk
text: it 's been confirmed that a `` small '' number of child migrants will be resettled in norfolk .
the county council says the priority will be tending to their needs .
whether or not to offer shelter to refugees and migrants has been a hot political issue in norfolk .
fifty syrian refugees are already due to arrive in norfolk from january as part of a government resettlement project .
but that was n't supported by all councillors .
during a vote on the issue in july , six ukip representatives voted against the plan after it was revealed it would cost the authority £ 400,000 .
today it was confirmed that unaccompanied child migrants fleeing war zones would also be relocated here .
it 's not been confirmed how many children will be helped , when they will come here or how much the scheme will cost norfolk county council .
author: Amy Barratt
BBC Radio Norfolk

documents.title: family 's tribute to man who drowned off norfolk
text: the family of leszek puchala has paid tribute to him after he drowned in the sea near great yarmouth .
his son , przemek and daughter-in-law katarzyna , who live in thetford , were at the hearing with their baby daughter .
their statement said : `` we would like to thank our father for always providing us with help , advice and his loving heart .
`` he was a very good man who never refused to help anybody a loving and decent husband , father of three and grandfather , and a loyal friend to many - around 200 people attended his funeral . ''

documents.title: rip tide drowning 'a tragic outcome '
text: an inquest in norwich today heard that medical fitness may have been a contributing factor in the death of a leszek puchala at sea palling .
norwich coroner 's court heard that mr puchala had coronary artherosclerosis , a furring up of the heart and arteries .
under stress , that may have contributed to him becoming unconscious and having collapsed .
area coroner yvonne blake gave a narrative conclusion , stating mr puchala got into difficulties while swimming and `` he was pulled ashore and rescued and resuscitation commenced .
unfortunately that did not succeed and he was pronounced dead at the scene '' .
she added that it was a `` really tragic outcome '' on what should have been a happy occasion .

ms blake passed on her sincere condolences to the family and also said several people who helped in the rescue , including 14-year-old david castleman from essex , have been recommended for awards by the royal humane society .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: sea palling locals 'know what to do in a rip current '
text: matthew steiner and his wife were at sea palling on the day that a man from poland got caught in a rip current and died .
today , an inquest into the death of 52-year-old leszek puchala heard a statement from mr steiner , which said he 'd seen four men in the water .
initially he 'd thought nothing was wrong , but then heard shouting : `` a man came running towards me , and i ran with him to see what was going on i saw something was wrong . ''

`` the two other men were about 50m from the beach , the water looked calm and still locals nearby said the rock barriers by the sea can make strong rip tides they know if they 're caught in the tide [ they should ] to go with the current and it 'll eventually come clear .

`` the other thing i 'd like to mention is the delay in people getting into the water to help was because it was not clear the four people were in distress - it appeared they were just having fun in the sea .
`` as soon as it was apparent they were in trouble , the public were very quick to help rescue . ''
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: north sea drowning : rip tide 'did n't appear to be strong that day '
text: norwich coroner 's court heard statements from several people who 'd been at norfolk 's sea palling beach on the day when a group of day trippers got caught in a rip tide .
neil ramsay , who does a lot of kite surfing in the area , is aware of the rip tides but his statement said `` they did n't appear to be strong that day '' .
mr ramsay ( saw the group in the water , shouting , but `` there were no signs of distress '' .
that changed about five minutes later , when he said people were waving and shouting in polish .
he dialled 999 and asked for the coastguard .
they advised mr ramsay to tell the people going into the water to come back , as they did n't want any more casualties .
he got a body board and went to help the larger man .
`` the man was unconscious , and looked in a bad way , '' he said .
`` i got him on the board to keep his head out of the water .
he kept slipping off the board , but i asked the girl to help keep him on the board . ''

a statement from another beach-goer , matthew steiner , said he 'd seen four people in the water , the noise was of people having a good time and it was a normal day on the beach - `` there was no indication anything was wrong '' .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: man jailed for sexually abusing his friends ' children
text: a man , who used his position of trust to abuse his friends ' children , has been jailed for 13 years .
adam aitken , 29 , from orton goldhay in peterborough , pleaded guilty to six serious sexual offences against children .
peterborough crown court heard how he befriended his five male victims , aged between eight and 14 , after forming close relationships with their parents and carers .
det ch insp jon mcadam , from cambridgeshire police , said aitken could have victims in other parts of the country .
`` given the level of offending shown by aitken , it is anticipated there could be other victims , '' he said .
`` we believe he had links to the bedfordshire , gloucestershire , hertfordshire , kent , lincolnshire , norfolk , northamptonshire , nottinghamshire , surrey , west yorkshire and scotland areas .
`` what is clear from the victim 's accounts was how aitken would groom them , buying gifts and taking them on holiday , and then sexually abuse them and threaten them in to silence . ''
he added aitken was a `` calculated and dangerous individual who positioned himself to gain the trust of parents and guardians to abuse children . ''
author: Stuart Bailey
BBC News

documents.title: daughter-in-law saw swimmers in difficulty
text: a polish man who drowned after getting caught in a rip current off the norfolk coast in july had come to the this country to visit his family .
in a statement for norwich coroner 's court , katarzyna puchala said her father-in-law , leszek , had come to the uk to visit her after she 'd given birth to her baby .
on the 23 july , she and her husband przemek , along with his brothers tomosz and sebastian and their father leszek , went to sea palling , arriving at 10:30 .
some of them went into the sea , while she stayed on the beach with a friend .
she heard shouting but ignored it initially , believing it to be someone kidding .
her statement went on to say she saw `` przemek swimming towards the beach , screaming , he was so close i thought he was joking .
i ran towards the beach and shouted 'help ' in english '' .
`` i ran towards tomosz , i was in shock somebody put him on a foam board and brought him to the beach , '' she said .
`` some other people pulled my father-in-law onto the beach a man was holding me and i was crying .
i saw him breathing he tried to say something , but he had a medical tube in his mouth . ''
`` a helicopter and lifeboat landed .
the people approached my partner and told me he was breathing .
`` they went to help my father-in-law .
they were using a machine .
they told me he had died '' .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: inquest concludes swimmer drowned
text: an inquest has heard how a teenager who swam into the sea to help a father and son in difficulties chose to help the son first because he had more life left in him .
leszek puchala , 52 , who was visiting from poland , and his son sebastian were caught in a rip tide at sea palling near great yarmouth in july .
norwich coroner 's court heard a statement from 14-year-old david castleton , from essex , in which he said he 'd swam into the sea , and found both men unconscious in the water .
he flipped them both over , put his arm around the younger man and began to pull him back to shore .
david said the `` younger man felt warmer as if he had more life in him i had lifeguard training and therefore felt confident going into the water '' .
another man brought mr puchala ashore later .
despite resuscitation attempts , he died at the scene .
area coroner yvonne blake concluded that mr puchala had drowned .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: eating cake for charity
text: the auction of `` kate 's bake-off cake '' on bbc radio norfolk 's chrissie jackson programme has raised more than £ 350 for bbc children in need .
and kate barmby , one of this year 's great british bake off contestants , was kept busy while the bids came in - she was judging our very own cake competition
there was a varied selection for kate to sample - including these scones made to her recipe by bbc look east 's mike liggins .
spoiler alert : he did n't win .
it was a tough decision but someone had to win .
third place went to debs , for her lemon and poppy seed ombre cake , with homemade lemon curd and vanilla buttercream .
this three-layered chocolate cake , with nutella and chocolate ganache was made by winnie , who even made the pudsey bears .
do n't you just love those roses ?
it took four hours to complete and came in second .
but the triumphant winner was clare - her three-tiered ginger cake with cinnamon cream went down a treat - and kate even asked for the recipe .
well done to everyone - and by the way , yes we did try them - and it was all for charity .
each slice meant another donation to children in need .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

text: a tourist resort is planning to welcome syrian refugees with a day out at the seaside when they come to norfolk in the new year .
the first group will arrive in norwich in january , where they 'll be housed .
hunstanton town council wants to offer them a helping hand with free day trips , and they say they 'll keep it simple .
we 're a community here and people would like to help - take them along the promenade , let them see what we 've got in this town and make friends with people . ''

documents.title: inquest into swimmer 's death
text: the inquest is to be held this afternoon into the death of a swimmer who drowned off the norfolk coast .
leszek puchala , 52 , was on holiday from poland , visiting his son , when the pair decided to go to the beach on 23 july .
the father and son went to sea palling , and headed out into the water for a swim .
the day trip turned into tragedy , when mr puchala got caught up in a rip current .
beach goers who heard shouts said they did n't initially understand as they were in polish .
mr puchala was pulled unconscious from the sea by a teenager from essex .
despite attempts to save him , he died at the scene .
his son , sebastian , was rescued .

documents.title: 'do n't attend a & e unless it 's an emergency ' asks hospital
text: all beds at the james paget university hospital in gorleston are occupied and its asking members of the public to use other health services if it is n't an emergency .
the level of demand for services has remained high over the last two weeks , and this is expected to continue over the weekend and into next week .
clinical staff are reviewing all patients on wards , and those that no longer need hospital-based care can either go home or be moved to other healthcare providers .

documents.title: king 's lynn stars plan winter shake-up
text: king 's lynn stars team manager rob lyon is likely to step down after their disappointing speedway season .
promoter buster chapman has told me that he 's planning to change the way the club is run after they finished just two places off the bottom of the elite league .
the stars won just ten of their 27 league meetings in 2016.. chapman hopes lyon will stay involved at the norfolk arena .
he said : `` that 's what rob wants to do .
he 's had a lot of years as team manager and i think it 's time to try something else . ''

BBC Radio Norfolk sport

documents.title: hughton talks up canaries ' attacking talent
text: former norwich city manager chris hughton will try to get one over his old club this weekend .
the canaries go to brighton in the championship tomorrow .
hughton has guided the seagulls up to second in the table while norwich are fourth .
hughton was in charge at carrow road for almost two years , leaving just before they were relegated from the premier league in 2014 .
`` in my time there wes hoolahan was a big influence and he continues to be a big influence .
he seems to get better with age . `` .
said hughton , who is also a former newcastle and birmingham manager .
author: Chris Goreham
BBC Radio Norfolk sport

documents.title: why is the county council funding slimming classes ?
text: dr louise smith is norfolk 's director of public health - and she explains why the county council is funding a private company to provide weight-loss classes for hundreds of obese people in norfolk .

`` if we do nothing , within five years 250,000 people in norfolk will be obese - it 's not just the weight but the health impact - high blood pressure , diabetes - costing our health service £ 1m - it 's an investment in all our futures . ''
those eligible for the classes will be from a specific group - they 'll have had a health check with their gp which will have highlighted their weight as a high risk factor for heart disease .
at the moment , 2,600 people in the county will attend the slimming groups - but dr smith says there are plans to increase this to 8,000 a year .
slimming world was chosen , she explains , after the council put out an advertisement for the service and they secured the bid .
slimming world is about changing habits for life , not just a diet for 12 weeks - but the person going to the course needs to want to lose weight . ''
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: losing weight was a life-changer
text: back to the story about council money being used to send overweight people to slimming classes
one woman who 's already lost weight with one of the classes is abby earl from norwich .
she said she reached a turning point three years ago after a birthday night out with friends , where she felt uncomfortable , self conscious and unhappy within herself .
she joined the slimming group - losing 5lbs ( 2.2kg ) in the first week .
three months later , she 'd lost 3st ( 19kg ) and her journey has continued - she went on to lose another 1.5st ( 9.5kg ) .
abby says losing the weight has changed her life - and career .
she 's now a consultant and team developer for the slimming group in norwich .
it 's important to stay in the weight loss group - take an hour every week to go there , you get your motivation and support - and it 's completely safe . ''
author: Caroline Kingdon

documents.title: slimming classes should aim for '10 % weight loss '
text: norfolk 's obesity problem is growing , with the numbers of overweight people expected to rise to around 250,000 by the end of the decade .
in a bid to reduce the cost to health and social services , the county council is paying for 2,600 people to attend a 12-week commercial slimming courses .
tam fry , from the national obesity forum says this will give people a start , but people should use the 12 weeks to set them on their way to keeping their weight down in the long-term .
they should be going for 10 % weight loss which will involve much more time , which needs a lot of resolve '' .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: public funds being spent on weight loss classes
text: norfolk county council is paying for more than 2,500 people to lose weight on a commercial slimming course .
it costs the council £ 140,000 a year to send people on the programme , which is about £ 15,000 less than if a person paid individually .
at the moment , around a quarter of the county 's population are overweight - that 's around 215,000 people .
it 's predicted that will rise to nearly a 250,000 by 2020 , costing local health and social services £ 100m a year .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: poppy appeal targets £ 700,000
text: the royal british legion launches its annual poppy appeal .
last year £ 700,000 was raised in the norfolk to support veterans , and it 's hoping to raise a similar amount this year .
county chairman john boisson says they 're very grateful for the volunteers who turn out every october and november to help with the collections .
one of the things the charity does in norfolk is provide a handyman service , helping people to live independently by putting in things like ramps and handrails .
mr boisson tells of an incident when a handyman , who 'd gone to a house to do adaptations , also recommended a carbon monoxide alarm be fitted .
a few days later it went off and when the fire service arrived the householder was told they probably would n't have woken up that night if there had n't been an alarm . ''
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: government minister rallies support for devolution
text: the secretary of state for local government has been visiting ipswich to try to rally support for the case for more regional government .
councils in suffolk are backing the idea , but there 's been some opposition in norfolk .

sajid javid , the minister in question , said : `` of course there 's a lot the government wants to achieve in terms of passing down more powers , a lot more money to invest in infrastructure , skills , transport , but at the end of the day it 's got to be local leaders working with local businesses to decide for themselves if it 's something that they want to do . ''
a devolution deal for suffolk and norfolk would allow the release of more government funds for the region .

documents.title: council 'will remove ' fly-grazing horses
text: a spokeswoman for norwich city council says they 've been in talks since may with a man who 's been ordered to stop his horses fly-grazing on land at mile cross .
they 've offered leonard jones an alternative grazing site , subject to him providing all the necessary documents for the horses .
the council said : `` mr jones does n't have grazing rights to the land in question - and it is not suitable for animal grazing .

`` the land where he 's currently grazing the horses has been earmarked for redevelopment as an extension of the existing traveller site , although this is still under consultation and not yet approved . ''
if mr jones does n't move the horses , the council says it will remove them and take them to the vets for a check-up and to be micro-chipped .
they will be re-homed at animal sanctuaries if necessary .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: horse owner ordered to move his animals on
text: an appeal has gone out for help in re-homing 15 horses after norwich city council told a man he had to move them for a second time .
leonard jones had previously had the horses for 15 years on 43 acres of land at bowthorpe , but was ordered to move them on because the land was `` overgrazed '' .
five months ago he moved his animals onto a small area of land behind the recycling centre at mile cross , but two days ago was given notice to stop the animals fly-grazing there .
he 's been given a deadline of 11:00 on friday , but fears his horses may have to be put down , as `` all the sanctuaries are full '' .
alternative grazing on earlham marshes has been offered for three of the animals , but he says this is unsuitable as it 's a flood plain .
i 've had horses all my life , all my family were all bred and born with horses .
horses are a gypsy man 's life and when you take them away , that 's his life finished , they 've destroyed a gypsy way of life . ''
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: pizza hut driver death : police condemn 'sickening , senseless crime '
text: the cambridgeshire police officer in charge of the investigation into ali qasemi 's death said his family `` have lost a loving , devoted husband and father , devastating their close-knit family - all for the price of three pizzas '' .
mark lintott ( left ) was found guilty of robbery and manslaughter , while joel lawson ( right ) admitted both charges before the peterborough crown court trial .
det insp lucy thomson said : `` this was a sickening , senseless crime , which has caused misery to mr qasemi 's wife and young sons . ''
author: Helen Burchell
BBC News

documents.title: pizza hut 'reviewed training ' following death
text: following the verdicts , pizza hut said it had reviewed its training methods for drivers following the death of ali qasemi .
`` since may we have put in place a number of measures including a new order verification process and a review of delivery driver safety training , '' a spokeswoman said .
the company had been `` extremely saddened '' by the news of mr qasemi 's death and had been `` working closely with our franchisee to support mr qasemi 's family '' , she added .

documents.title: pizza hut driver death : pair 'plotted to take food without paying '
text: during mark lintott 's trial , peterborough crown court heard he and joel lawson had been drinking with friends when they plotted to take the food without paying .
`` they intended to take it using threat or force , '' gregory perrins , prosecuting , said .
when pizza hut driver ali qasemi arrived , `` they came out of the flat intending to take those pizzas by force '' , he said .
lawson punched mr qasemi , causing him to fall and hit his head .
they left him dying on the pavement outside and went back in to continue partying , mr perrins said .
a passerby called an ambulance .
mr qasemi , a married father of two , died from a serious head injury following the attack on 8 may .
the court was told his wife fawzia was pregnant at the time of his death .
the jury returned a unanimous verdict on the robbery charge and a 11-1 majority on manslaughter against lintott .
author: Helen Burchell
BBC News

documents.title: man convicted of pizza hut driver killing
text: a man has been found guilty of killing a takeaway delivery driver in a `` snatch and grab '' robbery for three pizzas .
pizza hut worker ali qasemi , 45 , died in may , two days after he was punched and left dying on the pavement in peterborough .
mark lintott , 29 , from peterborough , denied robbery and manslaughter but was found guilty by a jury at the city 's crown court .
joel lawson , 25 , of norwich , admitted both charges ahead of the trial .
the pair will be sentenced on 18 november at cambridge crown court .
author: Helen Burchell
BBC News

documents.title: advice for disabled rail passengers
text: for rail passengers with mobility issues , any disruption to services can cause problems .

zara todd , from the equal lives campaign group , says the rail upgrade work taking place on the main line between norwich and london takes away the flexibility of travel , as disabled passengers will have to stick rigidly to booked plans .
disabled passengers are always advised to book in advance .

network rail area director steve hooker says by giving prior notice , it enables the rail operators make it as easy as possible for those with mobility issues to travel , and also to make any arrangements that may be needed .

documents.title: majority direction in pizza delivery man death trial
text: jurors in the trial of a man accused of killing a takeaway delivery driver in a `` snatch and grab '' robbery for three pizzas have been told they can return majority verdicts .
pizza hut worker ali qasemi , 45 , died in may , two days after he was punched and left dying on the pavement in peterborough .
mark lintott , 29 , of shrewsbury court , peterborough , denies robbery and manslaughter .
the judge in the case said the jury could return majority verdicts in which at least 10 of them were agreed .
peterborough crown court heard joel lawson , 25 , of goodhale road , norwich , admitted both charges ahead of the trial .

text: this is the scene on holkham beach today - the vehicle tracks are the only reminder that a whale was washed ashore here on thursday afternoon last week .
experts have said the 42ft ( 13m ) fin whale died of starvation - linked to a spinal abnormality .
fin whales , listed as endangered by the international union for conservation of nature ( iucn ) , are more seen in the deep ocean and rarely , if ever , in the north sea .

documents.title: pedalling for pudsey
text: the one show 's rickshaw challenge is back - setting off on its 470 mile journey from jedburgh in the scottish borders on friday , 11 november , travelling south to london .
a new team of riders is taking to the saddle to raise pounds for pudsey .
presenter matt baker will cycle alongside the rickshaw , ridden by six young riders who 've all been supported by bbc children in need projects .
day six will see the team cycle 60 miles from skegness , ending in king 's lynn .
the next day , they face another 60 mile ride - via downham market and ely before arriving in duxford .
the team of fundraisers hope to cross the finish line on friday , 18 november - in time for the bbc children in need show .
last year the challenge raised £ 4,123,634 for bbc children in need .

documents.title: many uses for a red phone box
text: some phone boxes in norfolk have n't been used for a single call in the last year , and now bt is holding a consultation to see if we really need 400 of them dotted around our county .
one option is for communities to join the `` adopt a kiosk '' scheme .
for the cost of £ 1 , they can be bought and transformed in a variety of ways - mini libraries , art galleries , cafes to name a few .
plumstead , near holt , adopted its box several years ago .
initially it was used as a noticeboard - but is now home to a defibrillator .
the ambulance service was offering them for free at the time , says resident julie brown ( below ) , but local fund-raising enabled them to buy the cabinet to house it .
`` we 're so isolated '' , she said , `` that if anyone were to dial 999 it would take an ambulance a long time to get here '' .
the defibrillator gives them a `` good chance '' of saving someone 's life .
it has n't yet been used , but one in a neighbouring village 's call-box has been used several times .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: how many of our phone boxes could disappear ?
text: earlier this week we told you of bt 's plans to remove the least-used public payphones from communities in north norfolk .
we can now give you a breakdown of the numbers of phone boxes that could soon disappear from across the whole county :
the telecoms company says it wo n't remove any phone box where there is no signal on any mobile phone network .

documents.title: dead whale removed from beach
text: the young fin whale which washed up at holkham beach last thursday became something of a tourist attraction .
in mild temperatures , it had been rapidly decomposing and natural england wanted to dispose of it as quickly as possible .
early this morning specialist contractors came to the beach to cut up the carcass and take it away to a rendering plant in lincolnshire .
now all that remains is the sweep of the beach , the vehicle tracks - and the smell left in the sand where it lay .
author: Jill Bennett
BBC Radio Norfolk

documents.title: network rail : upgrade work is best done when lines are less busy
text: steve hooker , area director of network rail , explains why there 'll be a shutdown of rail services over christmas .

`` it 's a quiet time- with only around 50 % of the normal numbers of passengers traveling - so carrying out this important work at this time affects the least amount of people we have to get this work done and it 's best to do at times when the lines are less busy , '' he said .
the work is not just for crossrail and the remodelling of the shenfield junction , said mr hooker , but also to speed up trains that run on the main lines from norfolk .
there 's a huge amount of work to be done , says mr hooker : `` the list is pretty long , but we 're getting through it and appreciate people 's patience while we get on with it . ''
we need to bring the railway up to the standards and reliability that people expect .
the journey is a little more difficult at the weekends with bus replacements , but it 's still possible to travel around . ''

documents.title: rail upgrade work is 'difficult ' for disabled passengers
text: rail passengers are facing more disruption , with a programme of works due to start on christmas eve continuing through to the end of march .
campaigners say the work to upgrade the norwich to london line could affect disabled passengers , with buses replacing trains while the work is carried out .
zara todd , from the equal lives charity , commutes from norwich to london .
she says the rail improvement work makes journeys challenging , particularly if trains are stopping earlier than their destination .
at the moment , disabled passengers travelling by rail have to give at least 24 hours notice , whether there 's engineering work or not .
when there is engineering work , says ms todd , they can end up getting stuck .
it causes a whole range of problems in terms of being somewhere you 're unfamiliar with , having to navigate buses or coaches - and having to rigidly stick to when you 're going to travel . ''

documents.title: calais volunteer says it 's 'good ' that 'the jungle ' is going
text: french authorities are in the process of clearing the migrant camp at calais known as `` the jungle '' , with thousands of people being taken to reception centres elsewhere in france .

james pearce , who founded an online group to link donors with migrants in the camp who need top-up phone credits , says it 's `` pretty essential '' for a migrant to have access to a phone during the eviction .

he said : `` if a child goes missing , i 'm contacted and asked to top up the number there are people there trying to get to the uk with or without phone credit , and the credit makes a difference if they find themselves in a life-threatening situation '' .
mr pearce , from wymondham , who 's volunteered at the camp , says the demolition of `` the jungle '' went well on the first few days , but descended into chaos .
it 's good that it 's going , as it 's not a sensible place to live .
i hope things work out as best as possible for the people that have lived there . ''
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: facebook page to help top-up migrants ' mobiles raises thousands
text: a south norfolk man says thousands of refugees have been helped by a group he set up to help them top up their mobile phones .
james pearce , who lives near wymondham , created the facebook page `` phone credit for refugees '' after volunteering in `` the jungle '' near calais , which has been cleared of people this week .

having phone credit , he says , gives the migrants the ability to sort things out for themselves , such as where their next accommodation will be , and access what services are available locally , as well as keeping in touch with family and friends .
his group now has 25,000 members , and has given away around £ 150,000 in phone top-ups .
clothing and food are essential , but phone credit can be easily supplied without having to go anywhere , or take big bundles of aid .
you can do it online and it 's a way of getting help person-to-person . ''
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

text: network rail is asking passengers travelling between norwich and london , and across to cambridge , to check before they travel , particularly at weekends , as further improvement works continue over christmas and into 2017 .
it says the work will deliver vital railway upgrades for the crossrail programme and remove long-standing heat-related speed restrictions .
but it means some journeys will be longer and involve rail replacement buses from essex into london , while the upgrades are being carried out .

documents.title: leader calls for additional devolution meeting
text: the leader of norfolk county council is asking for a special debate to discuss east anglian devolution .

the government wants to create a new combined authority for norfolk and suffolk , overseen by an elected mayor , but four authorities - great yarmouth , breckland , north norfolk and norwich - are against the deal as it stands .
a council meeting to approve the draft order to create the mayoral combined authority will take place on 21 november .
but norfolk county council leader cliff jordan wants a meeting to take place before then , to try and get an agreement between all authorities on a way forward .
`` since june , when four of the councils decided not to be involved , the whole landscape changed , '' mr jordan said .
`` i want to have direction to proceed from full council , before the final vote takes place . ''

documents.title: british sugar drops tomatoes for cannabis
text: british sugar is to swap growing tomatoes for a plant from the cannabis family , with the loss of a handful of jobs .
the company has been growing tomatoes at its wissington glasshouse for 16 years , and supplies 2 % of the uk tomato market .

but it says the cornerways nurseries will now be used for growing a non-psychoactive variety of cannabis which will go into a new medicine , used by gw pharmeceuticals , for the treatment of epilepsy in children .
managing director paul kenward said : `` we are extremely proud that our new crop will make a worthwhile contribution to the control of such a debilitating childhood disease . ''
the company is currently in consultation with unions over the job losses .
it is not known how many jobs will be lost .
author: Mariam Issimdar
BBC News

documents.title: inquest into vintage plane passenger death opens
text: an inquest has opened into the death of a passenger who was killed when the vintage aircraft he was travelling in crashed .
benjamin marshall was killed earlier this month when the plane crashed in a field near bungay and burst into flames .
the inquest was told mr marshall , 84 , a retired farmer from leicester , died of severe traumatic head injuries .
the norfolk area coroner yvonne blake adjourned the inquest until january , while a full report is compiled by the air accidents investigation branch .
the pilot of the aircraft , maurice hammond , from eye , remains in hospital .
author: Andrew Turner
BBC Radio Norfolk

documents.title: last day at european parliament 'very strange ' for richard howitt
text: richard howitt says it feels `` strange '' to be leaving his post as mep after more than two decades .
mr howitt announced he was standing down as labour mep for the east of england in september , and today is his last day in the role .
`` it 's pretty strange to walk into the european parliament as i did this morning knowing that this is the very last time i will do so , after 22 years .
`` i am proud of everything that i have done and very , very sad that britain will be leaving the european union . ''

documents.title: great yarmouth school could close down over row
text: an academy trust says a norfolk school could be closed down in a row about its lease .
the inspiration trust says it can not reach an agreement with the charity which owns the site of great yarmouth high school .
the trust wants a 125-year lease on the school site , but the freeholder , great yarmouth grammar school foundation , has offered a two-year rolling lease .
the row has held up the conversion of the school , which is in special measures , to an academy .
if talks fail , the inspiration trust says it could walk away from taking on the school .
norfolk county council has made no comment , and the department for education says it 's working with both sides on the future of the school .

documents.title: scammers take-over widow 's computer
text: an 81-year-old woman says a conman has left her `` absolutely petrified '' .
a man rang her , claiming to be from 'microsoft security ' , and asked her to turn on her computer before taking control of the device .
he did n't manage to get access to her bank account , after the woman sensed something was wrong and rang her bank , asking them to stop any further withdrawals .
but the caller did wipe all content from her laptop and the woman said she had to pay £ 100 to a firm to retrieve photos of her late husband from the computer 's hardrive .
the scam has previously been covered on watchdog .

documents.title: bennett : norwich do n't have problem killing games
text: norwich city defender ryan bennett says the canaries do n't have an issue with letting teams back into winnable games , despite last night 's league cup exit at leeds .
city twice went ahead , in normal and then extra-time , only for the hosts to peg them back and go on to win the penalty shoot-out .
bennett said : `` i do n't think there is a problem .
i think it 's just a coincidence it 's come in this run of games .
we 'll work hard to put that right and hopefully we 'll see that on saturday . ''
norwich travel to brighton this weekend for their next match in the championship .
author: Jay Lawrence
BBC Radio Norfolk

documents.title: canaries out of league cup on penalties
text: norwich city went out of the league cup last night at leeds , despite going ahead in both normal and extra time .
alex pritchard put the canaries 1-0 up in the first half before the yorkshire side equalised ahead of the break .
nelson oliveira then looked to have given city the win with an extra-time strike , but chris wood 's goal took the game to penalties .
pritchard , robbie brady and steven naismith then all missed their spot kicks to ensure leeds went through to the final eight of the competition .
author: Jay Lawrence
BBC Radio Norfolk

text: paralympic swimmer and rio medallist jessica-jane applegate has officially opened the redeveloped phoenix pool and gym in great yarmouth .
the borough council has spent £ 1.9m transforming the pool into a leisure centre which has a new health and fitness suite .

documents.title: appeal for dash cam footage after fatal collision
text: norfolk police investigating a fatal collision on the a47 last week want to hear from anyone who was driving in the area and using a dash cam .
it follows an incident on the eastbound carriageway , between the pullover and saddlebow roundabouts at king 's lynn , at around 18:45 on wednesday , 19 october .
a blue vauxhall zafira and a dark coloured ford fiesta were involved , which resulted in the zafira colliding with several road signs .
its driver and two passengers were taken to the queen elizabeth hospital for treatment .
one of the passengers , a woman in her 30s , died as a result of her injuries .
officers are appealing for anyone who may have seen either vehicle travelling on the a17 at sutton bridge to the a47 at king 's lynn between 18:30 and 19:00 to contact them .
they 're particularly keen to hear from any witnesses about the manner of driving of either vehicle .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: nurse is 'top educator '
text: a nurse at the james paget university hospital ( jpuh ) in gorleston has won an award for her work training the next generation of nurses and medical students .
sarah hills , who lives in lowestoft , has been in nursing for 10 years , five of them at the coastal hospital .
before that , she worked at barts and great ormond street hospitals .
ms hills has been named educator of the year in the eastern region by health education england .

documents.title: heathrow decision : what 's best for norwich airport ?
text: the managing director of norwich airport says the decision to build a third runway at heathrow airport has ended the uncertainty about the future of additional air capacity in the south east .
richard pace says the decision is positive , and they can now turn their attention to making sure that regional airports are also connected to the rest of the country .
the government 's regional air connectivity fund was used to launch the exeter-norwich route , and mr pace says they 'd like to press the government for a second round of such funding .
does he think a service between norwich and heathrow is a possibility ?
`` it is a possibility , but we have to look beyond and see what is best for norwich airport , '' he said .

do we want a connection to london or do we want the government to focus their energies on providing further rounds of regional air connectivity funding where we might wish to put routes from norwich to elsewhere ? ''
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: bottoms up ! the beer festival is under way
text: more than 20,000 lovers of real ales , beers and ciders are expected at st andrew 's and blackfriars ' halls this week , for the 39th norwich beer festival .
they 'll have a choice of 200 ales , 40 real ciders and more than 100 bottled beers from all over the world .
and if they 're not to your taste - how about a glass of wine ?
robert derbridge , from camra , who 's organised the event explains that some breweries are now venturing into wine production .
what does he think makes a good ale ?
`` a golden beer , something around 4 % , it 's light , easy to drink , and the flavours are just right around that percentage , '' he said .

mr derbridge does n't expect he 'll be sampling anything until tomorrow night , as he 's so busy organising the event and making sure everything is in the right place - so what will be the first that he 'll taste ?
i look through the list to see what we 've never had here before , which is why we do the festival .
it 's not just your locals - we bring in from all over the country . ''
blackfriars hall is filling up nicely .
all norfolk ales are in here along with games & @ twitterid # nchbeerfest
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: prisoners to get to work on bikes
text: unwanted bikes are to be reconditioned by inmates at wayland prison , helping them gain new skills , before they 're sold for charity .
the 21 bicycles were handed in at south norfolk council 's latest give and take reuse event in hingham .
cllr kay mason billig says the events have grown in popularity since they started off with just electricals , and later textiles , books and furniture .
`` a couple of years ago we started working with the men 's shed project so people could bring unwanted tools , we added unwanted paint and now it 's bikes , '' she said .
in hingham , over one tonne of material has been reused or recycled , with residents taking home nearly 200 items for reuse .
in total , since the council 's first event in 2010 , 130 tonnes of materials have been collected which may otherwise have ended up in landfill .

if norwich come back with a win , they 'll only be three games away from the final at wembley stadium .

i 'm putting out the best team that i think is going to try and win the game , but make sure that we do n't try and leave ourselves vulnerable for the weekend .
i think that 's just common sense and good management . ''

documents.title: conman fowler gave dodgy cheque to ex-pat in spain earlier this month
text: norman fowler had been up to his old tricks in spain before being arrested on a european arrest warrant , the bbc can reveal .
earlier this year we reported how fowler , 38 , from colchester , had tried to sell a car to ex-pat diana lindsay-vosper .
the vehicle turned out to be stolen .
we informed essex police of his whereabouts and on october 10 he was finally arrested under a european arrest warrant .
but prior to that fowler had conned another ex-pat , who did n't want to be named , out of 2,500 euros by passing him a cheque which bounced .
the man told me : `` nobody believed he could be a fraudster as he was such a sad-looking guy .
he had the perfect cover . ''

documents.title: norman fowler conned videographer out of £ 21,000
text: the victim of conman norman fowler set up a website to expose him and track him down .
videographer tom tailford , from norfolk , had camera equipment worth £ 21,000 stolen by fowler in 2012 .
he had rented the equipment to fowler after being contacted by him on internet sales site gumtree , but it was never returned and no fees were paid .
fowler , 38 , from colchester , had been found guilty of fraud and sentenced to nine months in jail at norwich crown court , but went on the run before he could be jailed .
the bbc tracked him down to pedregeur in spain in may .
he has now been arrested under a european arrest warrant issued to essex police .
author: Craig Lewis
BBC News

documents.title: fraudster norman fowler held in spain under european arrest warrant
text: serial conman norman fowler , 38 , arrested in spain under a european arrest warrant on october 10 , had gone missing in 2014 after being sentenced to nine months in jail at norwich crown court .
in may , the bbc tracked him down to alicante , where he had been renting an apartment from a british businesswoman .
he had been arrested by police in spain for unrelated gun licensing matters .

fowler , whose last known address in the uk was at propelair way , colchester , was later bailed by spanish police , but has now been re-arrested and remains in custody while extradition proceedings take place .
author: Craig Lewis
BBC News

documents.title: wanted man arrested in spain as part of £ 21k ebay fraud
text: a man wanted by police for online fraud worth £ 21,000 has been arrested in spain .
norman fowler was wanted by police in essex and norfolk for fraud using gumtree and ebay totalling £ 21,000 with at least nine victims .
the 38-year-old was detained on 10 october after a european arrest warrant was made .
he remains in spanish custody while extradition proceedings are processed .

documents.title: the cost of protecting norfolk from future flooding
text: a new report says up to £ 500m could be needed to protect the county from flooding .
the report , commissioned by the broads climate partnership ( bcp ) , looks at how to protect homes and businesses from rising sea levels and forecasts of warmer and wetter winters .
consultants looked at the strategies in place to manage flood risk for the eccles to winterton coast , broadland and great yarmouth .
the review found that despite the successful implementation of these strategies , to continue them will require an ongoing commitment and a considerable amount of work .
it revealed the total costs over the next 50 years are projected to be up to £ 500m .
under current funding eligibility rules , central government grand aid will not meet all of that cost .

documents.title: companies 'devastated ' after driver suffers life-changing injuries
text: the following statement has been issued by tw page , following its £ 80,400 fine for an incident in which jonathan howes was left with life-changing injuries when a drilling rig he was working on hit an overhead power cable at felmingham :
`` the company appeared at norwich crown court yesterday alongside lf papworth limited in relation to an incident that took place in april 2014 .
`` the company has always admitted responsibility for its part in the incident .
`` the company was devastated by the injuries suffered by mr howes and made it clear in court how sorry we are for what he has been through .

`` the judge recognised that we are a long-standing local company , with family values and we have taken comfort in the judge 's recognition that we are a company of integrity and that he had no doubt that we had taken the appropriate remedial action . ''
lf papworth , which was fined £ 134,000 , said it was `` devastated by mr howe 's injuries and have made it clear how sorry [ we ] are for what happened '' .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: companies fined £ 200,000 after man burnt by power line on farm
text: two firms have been fined after a lorry driver was left with serious burns after getting an electric shock at a farm in north norfolk .
jonathan howes was working with three other men on a farm owned by lf papworth ltd at felmingham , near north walsham , when the accident happened in april 2014 .
they 'd been employed by engineers tw page , who 'd been contracted by papworth to drill a borehole for water .
mr howes had been operating the mast of the drilling rig , being driven by another man , when it hit an overhead powerline .
he was airlifted to the specialist burns unit at broomfield hospital in essex .
more than 800 homes in the area were left without power .
both companies had previously admitted liability under the health and safety at work act .
at norwich crown court yesterday , tw page was fined £ 80,400 with £ 6,596 costs .
lf papworth ltd received a fine of £ 134,000 , with £ 6,484 costs .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: diabetes study participant 'shocked ' at sugar content of foods and drinks
text: the norfolk diabetes prevention study is about adult onset type 2 diabetes , and aims to help those who might be at risk of developing the condition .
one of those who 's taken part in the study is carole kirk , from mulbarton , following a blood test at her doctor 's surgery which showed she was bordering on the pre-diabetes line .
the sugar content of food and drink was shocking , she discovered .
she said : `` you do n't realise the amount of foods you eat are full of sugar even low-fat things , which are full of sugar . ''
before she joined the study , carole says she used to eat anything - but now is very careful when it comes to fat and sugar , only having sugar-free drinks , not fizzy drinks .
i 've always had sugar all my life , once i stopped i lost the taste for it .
you can have a bit of cake now and again , but you 've got to be sensible .
if i have a piece of cake it 's only half the size i 'd have had before . ''
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: 'some surgeries have 8,000 patients with type 2 diabetes '
text: professor mike sampson , of the norfolk and norwich university hospital ( nnuh ) is an expert on diabetes , a condition which affects blood sugar regulations .
he runs the norfolk diabetes study , which is the largest of its kind in the world .

there are some gp surgeries in norfolk , he says , that have 8,000 patients or more with type 2 diabetes , leading to `` big issues around practice nurse pressures and hours , and pressures on retinal screening and food care services '' .
a diagnosis of diabetes , he explains , `` is distressing '' and has a big impact on what a patient 's medical care will be .
`` your gp may talk to you about needing statins or blood pressure treatment , you may need to take diabetes tablets to keep blood glucose control better , or you may need insulin , '' he said .
there are so many people with diabetes in norfolk at the moment that something like 17 % or 18 % of inpatients at the norfolk and norwich university hospital have got diabetes .
it 's a very big pressure on health services . ''
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: numbers with type 2 diabetes more than doubles in two decades
text: the number of people in norfolk developing type 2 diabetes is a public health disaster , and it 's increasing at a worrying rate .
that 's the view of professor mike sampson , an expert on the condition at the norfolk and norwich university hospital .
around 17,000 people in the county had the condition 20 years ago , but now it 's up to 40,000 and could reach 70,000 by 2035 .
type 2 diabetes is different from type 1 , which often begins in childhood and is not related to diet or lifestyle .
type 2 is far more common , and is often associated with obesity .
it can lead to serious complications , including kidney failure , blindness and heart disease - and is the most common cause of loss of vision and blindness in people of a working age .

it 's also responsible for most lower limb amputations other than accidents - and those with type 2 diabetes are up to five times more likely to have cardiovascular disease such as stroke , than those without diabetes .
the symptons of type 2 diabetes : feeling very thirsty , feeling very tired , weight loss and passing urine more often , particularly at night .

documents.title: plans to remove least-used public payphones from communities
text: bt has written to north norfolk district council to confirm the start of a 90-day consultation over the removal of the least-used public payphones in the area .

consultation notices have been placed on 74 payphones , and the council has written to the affected town and parish councils asking for comments on the proposed removal , which they will feed back to bt .

communities are also being asked by the telecommunications company if they wish to join the adopt a kiosk scheme , which allows a community to acquire any of the traditional red heritage phone boxes .

documents.title: sandscaping proposal to help coastal communities
text: over the past 10 years , north norfolk district council ( nndc ) has invested £ 1.3m in maintaining the sea wall and revetments at bacton and walcott , but continued maintenance of the groynes is limited because of falling beach levels .

the cabinet is being asked to approve a proposal which could involve `` sandscaping '' to help bolster sea defences , and also to recommend that £ 500,000 is set aside as part of nndc 's contribution to the scheme .
councillor angie fitch-tillett says it 's a `` once in a lifetime opportunity '' to help the two communities .
the bacton gas terminal operators may have to consider going ahead with their self-funded coastal protection if money can not be found for a wider public scheme .
any scheme would require planning permission and marine consent , and also involve public consultation .
shell uk has recently applied for consents for construction of temporary defences as an interim measure .

documents.title: plans to protect villages from flooding
text: proposals to bolster sea defences at bacton and walcott for the next 20 years are to be discussed by north norfolk district council .
the villages , and bacton terminal , are at risk of coastal erosion due to falling beach levels and rising sea levels .
recently the local communities have started a petition calling for improved defences .
under the proposals , the shoreline would be `` sandscaped '' , where high volumes of additional sand would then be distributed by natural processes along the coastline .

the technique has been used successfully in the netherlands , and it 's believed it represents the best chance of sustaining the defences while ensuring the gas infrastructure at the gas terminal is protected .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: parent 's tribute to backpacker son who died in vietnam
text: a post-mortem examination that was conducted in the uk on backpacker aiden webb 's body noted cuts and scratches found by climbing , but no fractures or haemorrhages .
yvonne blake , area coroner for norfolk , recorded an open conclusion at a hearing at the coroner 's court in norwich earlier today .
ms blake said that it was known mr webb , who was born in norwich , had been trying to climb vietnam 's fansipan mountain alone , and got into difficulties .
`` he was injured , and had a deep cut on his arm he 'd badly hurt his knee and could n't move very well we know he was found in a stream , '' she said .
she extended her condolences to the family of 22-year-old , none of whom attended the hearing .
his parents , simone taylor and trever webb , said in a written statement : `` aiden was such a joy to be around .
`` we 're incredibly close as a family and feel privileged to have been his parents '' .
they praised everyone who 'd been involved in the recovery of their son 's body .
mr webb had been a student at anglia ruskin university in cambridge .
author: Caroline Kingdon

documents.title: coastal walk includes beaches and seaside town
text: good news for those who love walking - a new section of the england coast path opens in north norfolk today .
it stretches for 21 miles ( 34km ) from sea palling , through the wildlife haven of winterton ( and horsey dunes , before reaching hopton-on-sea .
it includes beaches , dunes and trees - contrasting with the lively resort of great yarmouth with its entertainments and maritime heritage .

the england coast path is expected to be finished by 2020 , and when complete it will be stretch 2,795 miles ( 4,500 km ) around the country 's coastline making it one of the longest coastal walking routes in the world .

documents.title: backpacker 's body was embalmed
text: an inquest has heard how the girlfriend of a climber who was found dead in water on the tallest mountain in vietnam had pleaded with him to get help when he got into difficulty .

aiden webb , 22 , who was from norwich and studied at anglia ruskin university in cambridge , was climbing mount fansipan when he tried to make his way around a landslide and lost the trail path , his girlfriend bluebell baughan said in a written statement .
ms baughan , who was also in vietnam , stayed in contact with mr webb by text messages and facebook posts .
in a final text message , he agreed that ms baughan should raise the alarm and request help .
her reply failed to get through to his phone .
the body of mr webb was found in water in a ravine almost a week later .
his parents requested that a post-mortem examination was not carried out in vietnam .
after his body was repatriated to the uk , an examination failed to establish a cause of death , partly because the body had been embalmed .
area coroner for norfolk , yvonne blake , recorded an open conclusion at norfolk coroner 's court in norwich .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: why was norfolk chosen for alan partridge ?
text: if you 've ever wondered why norfolk was chosen as the home for fictional dj alan partridge , steve coogan explains the decision was taken a long time ago .
`` norfolk , and norwich , are geographically unique - norwich is an isolated city , it suited his character - it 's its own thing , not north or south , a maverick status .
`` the midlands had been used a lot , liverpool over-used , and the north and south had been done you have to find somewhere that has n't been used before . ''

steve coogan is the creator of the inane television and radio presenter , and in his new book `` nomad '' alan walks the 160 miles from norfolk to the dungeness nuclear power station on the kent coast .
but what else is in the pipeline for partridge ?
steve says there are plans to bring him back to tv in some way , maybe another `` mockumentary '' like scissored isle .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: aha ! the popularity of radio legend alpha papa
text: alan partridge - the norfolk radio legend , portrayed by actor and comedian steve coogan .
but what makes the fictitional dj so popular ?
a short while ago , steve coogan explained to bbc radio norfolk 's chrissie jackson why he believes people like the `` national treasure '' .
`` a lot of people think 'there but for the grace of god go i ' , he says things that people think but do n't say out loud they empathise with him and share his anxieties , '' he said .
partridge is not known for his politically correctness , as steve explains .
`` he tries to be pc alan is n't so much a reactionary right wing little englander , it 's more like he 's trying to be economically conservative but socially progressive '' .
`` over the years he 's developed into something that has a resonance with people , reflecting changing attitudes in britain , reflecting their lives and becoming part of the furniture '' .
he 's like a relative nice to visit but you do n't want to live with him . ''
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: georgey spanswick to become full-time host of local radio evening show
text: georgey spanswick , who currently presents bbc local radio 's friday 19:00-22:00 show , will front it five days a week when regular host mark forrest stands down in february .
georgey , who currently also hosts the breakfast show on bbc radio york , said : i 've loved presenting the friday evening show for the last year and a bit .
`` so to be able to present the show five nights a week is fantastic . ''

mark forrest , who 's moving on after presenting the programme from monday to thursday since it replaced regional shows in 2013 , said : `` i 'm proud of the show we have produced for the last four years and i 'm pleased to be moving on when the audience figures indicate the show is in great shape . ''
the evening show is broadcast on all 39 bbc local radio stations in england .

documents.title: vietnam backpacker 's inquest records open verdict
text: an open verdict has been recorded into the death of norfolk backpacker aiden webb .
the 22-year-old died while attempting to climb vietnam 's highest mountain in june .
the medical cause of death remains `` unascertained '' .
vietnamese authorities suggested mr webb had drowned after falling into a stream and becoming unconscious .
he had been a student at anglia ruskin university in cambridge .
author: Kim Riley
BBC Look East

documents.title: dead whale 'ill for some time '
text: experts say the whale which washed ashore in north norfolk last week would have struggled to swim properly because of a spinal deformity .
the 42ft ( 13m ) juvenile fin whale was found on holkham beach on thursday .
dr ben garrod from anglia ruskin university says it would have been ill for some time before dying .
the juvenile female had `` massively poor nutritional content '' with very little in her stomach and `` really poor muscle content there '' .
it became very apparent the pelvic area was kinked , with a huge lump or distortion there . ''
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: norfolk duo await fa vase draw
text: gorleston and thetford town will be flying the flag for norfolk when the draw for the second round of the fa vase is made at lunchtime .
thetford beat norfolk rivals great yarmouth town 2-1 on saturday , while gorleston were 2-0 winners over barking .
swaffham town fell at the first round stage .
they lost 6-0 to peterborough sports .
author: Chris Goreham
BBC Radio Norfolk sport

documents.title: do you want to play ed sheeran 's drums ?
text: if you 've ever dreamed of playing ed sheeran 's drum kit , here 's your chance .
a kit used by ed sheeran as a teenager is being auctioned in aid of the east anglia 's children 's hos ( each ) .

the international superstar signed it during a visit to the charity 's treehouse hos in ipswich , with the inscription `` this is my old drum kit , love ed sheeran '' , and has agreed to pen a further personal message to the highest bidder at the end of the auction .
the bright orange drum kit , with green snare , is included as a lot in the ultimate charity auction which started on saturday and runs until sunday , 6 november .
the donation is in support of the each nook appeal , which is raising funds to build a new hos on the outskirts of norwich .
the framlingham singer-songwriter is an ambassador of the charity , and will be performing live at an each gala dinner at the natural history museum in november .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: care system 'teeters on the brink of collapse '
text: the north norfolk liberal democrat mp and former coalition care minister norman lamb says it 's `` dreadful and shameful '' that better healthcare is not prepared to be called to account over its decision to walk away from a contract to look after some of the county 's most vulnerable people .
the company signed a contract with the county council last november , but has had problems since then , with carers turning up late or not at all .
it 's now been rated as `` inadequate '' by inspectors and the contract finishes next month .
speaking on bbc radio norfolk earlier , mr lamb says there are also question marks over the county council 's role , and how long they knew the service was failing .
the problem is seen across the uk , says mr lamb , with not enough money spent nationally on the social care system .
when companies sign up to contracts with insufficient funds available , they ca n't recruit sufficient numbers of care staff .
care staff do the most vital work on very low earnings and the whole system teeters on the brink of collapse . ''
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: witness appeal following collision between motorcycle and car
text: police are appealing for witnesses to a serious road traffic collision in little cressingham , west of watton , yesterday .
a motorcycle and a silver ford fiesta were involved on the b1108 brandon road , which happened at about 16:40 .
a man in his 50s , who was riding the motorcycle , was taken to the queen elizabeth hospital in king 's lynn with serious back and chest injuries .
he was later transferred to addenbrooke 's hospital in cambridge where his condition is said to be critical but stable .

documents.title: howson injury 'really frustrating '
text: howson injury 'really frustrating '

documents.title: 'you can not care without carers '
text: more on the collapsed care contract
eric goleby , 75 , who lives with his wife sally in hickling , says there have been problems with the service provided by better healthcare since the company took over in november 2015 .
sally goleby , who is totally disabled , can not feed herself or drink , and has to be hoisted onto a chair , the bed or a settee .
carers come for one hour in the morning to get her up , showered and dressed and take her through to the lounge .
they come again at lunchtime to check she is ok , returning later in the afternoon and then at 19:30 to put her to bed .
two carers are needed , says eric , as his wife needs hoisting everywhere , but often `` only one turns up as the company has no-one to cover the shift '' .

mr goleby has received a letter informing him better healthcare 's contract will finish on 21 november , but he says many of its carers are leaving before that date , and is concerned at what will happen between now and then .
he does n't know who 'll be providing the care after that date , but says the new company `` has got to guarantee they 'll have enough staff you can not care without carers '' .
author: Caroline Kingdon
BBC Local Live

documents.title: a148 to be closed for some time
text: emergency services are at the scene of a serious road traffic collision on the a148 at hillington .
norfolk police were called to the scene at 07:00 following reports of a collision involving a lorry and a motorcycle near to bunkers hill .
the road is expected to be closed for some time .
diversions have been set up via the b1153 to gayton , the b1145 to the rougham crossroads and the a1065 to fakenham .
visit bbc travel for more updates .

documents.title: care provider walks away from contract
text: a failing care firm is walking away from its contract to look after some of norfolk 's most vulnerable people .
better healthcare has been heavily criticised by the regulator , the care quality commission ( cqc ) .
the firm provides in-home care to around 100 people in norwich and north norfolk .
but the cqc has rated the firm `` inadequate '' and has placed it in `` special measures ' '' .
inspectors found that carers were often late to arrive and sometimes missed calls altogether .
the firm , which began its contract with norfolk county council in november last year , struggled from the start with many unhappy carers resigning .
in april , the cqc told the company it needed to improve , and better healthcare said it had been on a recruitment drive .
the latest cqc report praises staff , but is highly critical of management .
it says the service was `` not well-led '' , `` not consistently safe '' and that complaints were not addressed .
in a statement , norfolk county council said the norfolk-based care providers leaf and nr care would take on the work by `` the end of november '' .
it also said that `` at no point will anyone be left without a homecare service '' .
better healthcare has not responded for comment .
author: Paul Moseley
BBC Radio Norfolk

documents.title: canaries hit by howson injury blow
text: norwich city midfielder jonny howson is unlikely to play again before christmas after having surgery on an ankle injury .
the news was confirmed by the canaries ' manager alex neil after the 1-0 defeat by preston at the weekend which saw city drop to fourth in the championship .
howson has missed norwich 's last three games , but had scored three goals in 11 games this season before that .
neil said : `` he had surgery to fix his ankle/heel type area and we 're going to be missing him for quite a few weeks . ''
author: Chris Goreham
BBC Radio Norfolk sport

norfolk police advise motorists to find alternative routes .
travel will have updates .
